title: Genesis Chapter 24 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Genesis chapter 24 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Genesis Chapter 24 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Genesis Chapter 24.

questions.question: Who did Abraham send to find a wife for his son Isaac?
options: His eldest servant
His son Ishmael
His brother Nahor
A stranger from Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: His eldest servant
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:2 shows Abraham sending his eldest servant to find a wife for Isaac.

questions.question: What oath did Abraham make his servant swear by?
options: The LORD, the God of heaven and earth
The gods of Canaan
The sun and moon
The spirits of his ancestors
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD, the God of heaven and earth
questions.explanation: In Genesis 24:3, Abraham made his servant swear by the LORD, the God of heaven and the earth.

questions.question: Where was the servant instructed to find a wife for Isaac?
options: From Abraham's own country and kindred
From the daughters of the Canaanites
From Egypt
From the city of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: From Abraham's own country and kindred
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:4 instructs the servant to find a wife from Abraham's country and kindred.

questions.question: What was the servant's concern about his mission?
options: The woman might not want to follow him
The camels might run out of water
Isaac might refuse the wife
The journey would be too short
questions.correctAnswer: The woman might not want to follow him
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:5 records the servant's worry that the woman might not be willing to go with him.

questions.question: What sign did the servant pray for to identify the right wife for Isaac?
options: A woman who offers water to him and his camels
A woman wearing a golden earring
A woman who comes from Canaan
A woman who speaks his language
questions.correctAnswer: A woman who offers water to him and his camels
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:14 describes the servant's prayer for a woman who offers water to him and his camels as the sign.

questions.question: Who came to the well with a pitcher on her shoulder?
options: Rebekah
Sarah
Milcah
Rachel
questions.correctAnswer: Rebekah
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:15 identifies Rebekah coming to the well with a pitcher on her shoulder.

questions.question: How did the servant respond when Rebekah offered him a drink?
options: He drank and then asked about her family
He immediately gave her gifts
He refused to drink
He told her to wait for Isaac
questions.correctAnswer: He drank and then asked about her family
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:18-23 show the servant drinking and then asking about her family and lodging.

questions.question: What gifts did the servant give to Rebekah upon meeting her?
options: A golden earring and two bracelets
A silver ring and necklace
A robe and sandals
A staff and bread
questions.correctAnswer: A golden earring and two bracelets
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:22 records the servant giving Rebekah a golden earring and two bracelets.

questions.question: Who is Laban in relation to Rebekah?
options: Her brother
Her father
Her uncle
Her cousin
questions.correctAnswer: Her brother
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:29 identifies Laban as Rebekah's brother.

questions.question: What did Laban say when he invited the servant into their house?
options: I have prepared the house and room for the camels
You must wait outside
We have no room to lodge
You should return to Abraham
questions.correctAnswer: I have prepared the house and room for the camels
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:31 records Laban inviting the servant inside and saying he has prepared the house and room for the camels.

questions.question: True or False: The servant ate before telling his errand to Laban and Bethuel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:33 states the servant refused to eat until he had told his errand.

questions.question: True or False: Abraham's servant believed the LORD had prospered his way after meeting Rebekah.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:48 shows the servant worshipping and blessing the LORD for leading him rightly.

questions.question: True or False: Laban and Bethuel refused to allow Rebekah to marry Isaac.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:50-51 states they said the matter was from the LORD and gave permission.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Rebekah's family blessed her, saying, 'Be thou the mother of ________.'
options: thousands of millions
a few children
one son
a mighty nation
questions.correctAnswer: thousands of millions
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:60 contains the blessing 'Be thou the mother of thousands of millions.'

questions.question: What did Isaac do when he saw Rebekah coming from the camels?
options: He went out to meet her
He stayed inside
He sent servants to greet her
He hid in the tent
questions.correctAnswer: He went out to meet her
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:63 records Isaac going out to the field and seeing the camels coming.

medium.title: Genesis Chapter 24 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Genesis Chapter 24 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Genesis 24 teach us about trusting God's guidance when making important decisions?
options: By praying for a clear sign and trusting God to lead the way
By making quick decisions without seeking God's will
By relying solely on human wisdom and planning
By delaying decisions until circumstances are perfect
questions.correctAnswer: By praying for a clear sign and trusting God to lead the way
questions.explanation: The servant prays for God's guidance to identify the right wife for Isaac (Genesis 24:12-14, 42-48). This shows the importance of seeking God's direction through prayer and trusting His providence.

questions.question: What does the servant's oath under Abraham's thigh teach about honesty and integrity in our commitments?
options: It shows the seriousness of making a solemn vow and commitment
It encourages making promises without thought
It suggests vows can be broken easily
It promotes secrecy over accountability
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the seriousness of making a solemn vow and commitment
questions.explanation: Abraham makes his servant swear by putting his hand under his thigh, a solemn oath emphasizing integrity and faithfulness to his master's instructions (Genesis 24:2-3, 9).

questions.question: A fellow believer is anxious about finding a spouse. Based on Genesis 24, what biblical truth would you share about seeking a partner?
options: Trust in God’s timing and guidance, and pray for His leading
Rely only on personal attraction and feelings
Ignore spiritual compatibility
Choose quickly to avoid being alone
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s timing and guidance, and pray for His leading
questions.explanation: The servant's careful prayer and trust in God's guidance to find Rebekah (Genesis 24:12-14, 42-48) teach believers to seek God's will and timing in marriage decisions.

questions.question: How does Abraham's servant demonstrate humility and dependence on God in his mission?
options: By praying for success and acknowledging God's sovereignty
By boasting of his own wisdom and ability
By ignoring God’s role in the outcome
By forcing plans without prayer
questions.correctAnswer: By praying for success and acknowledging God's sovereignty
questions.explanation: The servant humbly prays for the LORD to prosper his journey and show kindness to Abraham (Genesis 24:12, 26-27, 42-48), showing reliance on God rather than self.

questions.question: What lesson about obedience can we learn from the servant’s actions in Genesis 24?
options: Obey God's commands faithfully even when the mission is difficult
Obey only when tasks are easy and convenient
Disobey instructions if unsure of success
Rely on personal judgment over God's instructions
questions.correctAnswer: Obey God's commands faithfully even when the mission is difficult
questions.explanation: The servant follows Abraham’s instructions to find a wife for Isaac, traveling far and trusting God despite uncertainties (Genesis 24:3-10, 42-49), exemplifying obedience.

questions.question: True or False: Abraham instructed his servant to take a wife for Isaac from the daughters of the Canaanites.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Abraham explicitly told his servant not to take a wife for Isaac from the daughters of the Canaanites but from his own country and kindred (Genesis 24:3-4, 37-38).

questions.question: What does Rebekah’s willingness to leave her family and go with Abraham’s servant teach about faith and trust?
options: It shows faith in God’s plan and trust in His provision
It shows recklessness and impatience
It shows selfishness
It teaches to avoid change
questions.correctAnswer: It shows faith in God’s plan and trust in His provision
questions.explanation: Rebekah agrees to go with the servant after consulting her family, demonstrating faith and trust in God's leading (Genesis 24:58-59, 60).

questions.question: How does this passage encourage generosity in daily life?
options: By showing Abraham’s servant giving gifts of gold and silver to Rebekah and her family
By hoarding wealth for personal use
By refusing to share blessings
By demanding payment for services
questions.correctAnswer: By showing Abraham’s servant giving gifts of gold and silver to Rebekah and her family
questions.explanation: The servant gives valuable gifts to Rebekah and her family as a sign of goodwill and blessing (Genesis 24:22, 53), illustrating generosity and stewardship.

questions.question: True or False: The servant immediately ate before explaining his mission upon arriving at Rebekah’s home.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The servant refused to eat until he had told his errand, showing patience and respect for the importance of his mission (Genesis 24:33-34).

questions.question: What does Isaac’s reaction to seeing Rebekah teach about love and courtship?
options: It teaches to honor and cherish the spouse with love and comfort
It advises indifference to a spouse
It encourages haste without respect
It suggests ignoring emotional connection
questions.correctAnswer: It teaches to honor and cherish the spouse with love and comfort
questions.explanation: Isaac loved Rebekah and was comforted after his mother’s death, showing the importance of love and care in marriage (Genesis 24:67).

questions.question: A believer struggles with patience in waiting for God’s timing. Based on Genesis 24, what encouragement can you share?
options: God’s timing is perfect; the servant waited and God led him to Rebekah
Impatience leads to better results
Waiting is a waste of time
One should act without consulting God
questions.correctAnswer: God’s timing is perfect; the servant waited and God led him to Rebekah
questions.explanation: The servant waits by the well at the right time and God directs the meeting with Rebekah (Genesis 24:11-15, 45-46), teaching patience and trust in God’s timing.

questions.question: How does Abraham’s servant demonstrate diligence and responsibility in his work ethic?
options: By taking all of Abraham’s goods and camels and carefully fulfilling his mission
By being careless and taking only a few items
By ignoring his master's instructions
By delaying the journey without cause
questions.correctAnswer: By taking all of Abraham’s goods and camels and carefully fulfilling his mission
questions.explanation: The servant took ten camels and all the master's goods entrusted to him, showing responsibility and diligence (Genesis 24:10).

questions.question: What does the interaction between Laban, Bethuel, and the servant teach about seeking God’s will in family decisions?
options: They recognized the matter as from the LORD and consented accordingly
They rejected the proposal without prayer
They made decisions based on personal preference only
They ignored the servant’s message
questions.correctAnswer: They recognized the matter as from the LORD and consented accordingly
questions.explanation: Laban and Bethuel acknowledge the event as from God and give their consent for Rebekah to marry Isaac (Genesis 24:50-51), showing submission to God’s will in family matters.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Abraham’s servant prayed for a sign that the woman who would give him water and also offer to ________ would be the chosen wife for Isaac.
options: give water to the camels
bring food to the servants
offer shelter for the night
sing a song
questions.correctAnswer: give water to the camels
questions.explanation: The servant prayed that the woman who offered him water and said she would also water his camels would be the one appointed for Isaac (Genesis 24:14, 44).

questions.question: How does Genesis 24 teach about humility and gratitude in our prayers?
options: By the servant bowing down and worshiping the LORD and blessing Him after God’s guidance
By demanding blessings without praise
By praying only for personal gain
By ignoring God’s role in success
questions.correctAnswer: By the servant bowing down and worshiping the LORD and blessing Him after God’s guidance
questions.explanation: The servant repeatedly bows and worships the LORD, giving thanks for God’s guidance and kindness (Genesis 24:26-27, 48, 52), demonstrating humility and gratitude.

questions.question: What practical lesson about hospitality and kindness is shown when Laban invites the servant to his house?
options: Welcoming strangers with generosity and providing for their needs
Ignoring visitors and leaving them outside
Demanding payment for lodging
Refusing to share resources
questions.correctAnswer: Welcoming strangers with generosity and providing for their needs
questions.explanation: Laban invites the servant in, gives food and provisions, and prepares lodging, illustrating biblical hospitality (Genesis 24:31-32).

hard.title: Genesis Chapter 24 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Genesis Chapter 24.

questions.question: What specific oath did Abraham make his servant swear before sending him to find a wife for Isaac?
options: Not to take a wife for Isaac from the daughters of the Canaanites
To bring Isaac back if no wife was found
To never return without a wife
To take a wife only from Abraham's household
questions.correctAnswer: Not to take a wife for Isaac from the daughters of the Canaanites
questions.explanation: Abraham commanded his servant to swear not to take a wife for Isaac from the daughters of the Canaanites among whom he dwelt, as stated in Genesis 24:3.

questions.question: What is the significance of the servant putting his hand under Abraham's thigh before swearing the oath?
options: It symbolizes the covenant of inheritance and authority
It was a common greeting in Mesopotamia
It was a ritual to invoke the angel of the LORD
It symbolized submission to Abraham's father
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the covenant of inheritance and authority
questions.explanation: Putting the hand under the thigh was a solemn gesture related to covenant and inheritance, indicating serious commitment to the oath, as seen in Genesis 24:2 and 24:9.

questions.question: Why did the servant take ten camels with him on the journey to Mesopotamia?
options: Because all the goods of Abraham were in his hand
To trade for a wife
To carry provisions for the journey
To show Abraham’s wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Because all the goods of Abraham were in his hand
questions.explanation: The text states that the servant took ten camels because all the goods of Abraham were in his hand, indicating he was fully entrusted with Abraham's wealth (Genesis 24:10).

questions.question: What was the specific sign the servant prayed for to identify the woman chosen for Isaac?
options: She would offer him water and also water his camels
She would greet him with bread
She would bring a gift from her family
She would recognize him immediately
questions.correctAnswer: She would offer him water and also water his camels
questions.explanation: The servant prayed that the woman who offered to give him water and also water his camels would be the one appointed by the LORD for Isaac (Genesis 24:14).

questions.question: How does Rebekah’s act of watering the camels serve as a typological foreshadowing in biblical theology?
options: It symbolizes hospitality and covenant blessing extended to God's chosen
It prefigures baptismal cleansing rituals
It foreshadows the servanthood of Jesus
It represents the crossing of the Red Sea
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes hospitality and covenant blessing extended to God's chosen
questions.explanation: Rebekah’s watering of camels is a cultural act of hospitality that also typifies God’s provision and blessing to His covenant people, reflecting covenantal themes throughout Scripture (Genesis 24:19-20).

questions.question: Which literary structure best describes the servant’s prayer and the immediate arrival of Rebekah?
options: Chiastic structure emphasizing divine providence
Parallelism illustrating human effort and divine response
Allegory depicting faithfulness
An acrostic poem praising God
questions.correctAnswer: Chiastic structure emphasizing divine providence
questions.explanation: The servant’s prayer and Rebekah’s arrival form a chiastic structure highlighting God's providential guidance, as the answer to prayer comes immediately (Genesis 24:12-15).

questions.question: What is the cultural significance of the servant giving Rebekah a gold earring and bracelets?
options: They served as betrothal gifts symbolizing commitment
They were used to pay her family’s debts
They were religious tokens for protection
They marked her as a servant of Abraham
questions.correctAnswer: They served as betrothal gifts symbolizing commitment
questions.explanation: The gold earring and bracelets were customary betrothal gifts, symbolizing the servant’s intention to secure a wife for Isaac (Genesis 24:22).

questions.question: How does the servant’s worship after meeting Rebekah reflect the theological theme of divine guidance?
options: It acknowledges God’s mercy and truth in leading him rightly
It shows gratitude for personal success
It is a ritual to confirm the marriage
It invokes angelic protection for the journey
questions.correctAnswer: It acknowledges God’s mercy and truth in leading him rightly
questions.explanation: The servant worshiped the LORD, blessing Him for not leaving Abraham destitute and leading him to the right house, emphasizing divine guidance (Genesis 24:26-27).

questions.question: True or False: The servant was compelled to wait several days at Rebekah’s home before receiving an answer about Isaac’s marriage proposal.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The servant was offered to stay and eat, but he requested to depart the next morning, indicating no prolonged waiting (Genesis 24:54-56).

questions.question: What role does Laban play in the narrative concerning Rebekah’s marriage to Isaac?
options: He is Rebekah’s brother who negotiates and welcomes the servant
He is the priest who blesses the marriage
He is a Canaanite opposing the marriage
He is Abraham’s servant accompanying the man
questions.correctAnswer: He is Rebekah’s brother who negotiates and welcomes the servant
questions.explanation: Laban, Rebekah’s brother, meets the servant at the well, welcomes him, and later gives consent for the marriage (Genesis 24:29-31, 50-51).

questions.question: Which phrase indicates the servant’s reliance on God’s sovereign will in choosing Isaac’s wife?
options: "The thing proceedeth from the LORD: we cannot speak unto thee bad or good."
"Wilt thou go with this man?"
"Behold, Rebekah is before thee, take her."
"And I bowed down my head, and worshipped the LORD."
questions.correctAnswer: "The thing proceedeth from the LORD: we cannot speak unto thee bad or good."
questions.explanation: This phrase by Laban and Bethuel acknowledges that the marriage arrangement is under divine control (Genesis 24:50).

questions.question: What is the significance of Rebekah covering herself with a veil when she meets Isaac?
options: It reflects modesty and respect in ancient Near Eastern marriage customs
It was a sign of mourning for Sarah
It indicated she was a foreigner
It was a royal gesture of status
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects modesty and respect in ancient Near Eastern marriage customs
questions.explanation: Rebekah covered herself with a veil upon seeing Isaac, a customary sign of modesty and proper conduct in marriage contexts (Genesis 24:65).

questions.question: How does Genesis 24 connect typologically to the Pauline epistle Galatians 4:22-31 regarding Isaac and the covenant?
options: Isaac represents the child of promise, prefiguring the new covenant in Christ
Isaac is a symbol of law-based righteousness
Rebekah’s family is a metaphor for Gentile inclusion
The servant’s oath parallels baptismal vows
questions.correctAnswer: Isaac represents the child of promise, prefiguring the new covenant in Christ
questions.explanation: Paul in Galatians 4 uses Isaac as a typological figure of the promise and freedom in Christ, contrasting with the law represented by Ishmael; Genesis 24 narrates Isaac’s marriage as part of the covenant lineage (Genesis 24; Galatians 4:22-31).

questions.question: What cultural practice in Genesis 24 highlights the importance of family lineage and kinship in ancient Near Eastern marriage customs?
options: Seeking a wife from the servant’s master's kindred and country
Public announcements in the city gate
Sacrificial offerings at the wedding
Bride price paid directly to the bride
questions.correctAnswer: Seeking a wife from the servant’s master's kindred and country
questions.explanation: Abraham commands the servant to find a wife for Isaac from his own family and country, emphasizing kinship and lineage (Genesis 24:4, 38).

questions.question: Which Hebrew term in Genesis 24 underlines God’s faithfulness in fulfilling the promise to Abraham regarding his seed?
options: Chesed (kindness/mercy)
Shalom (peace)
Raah (shepherd)
Malak (angel/messenger)
questions.correctAnswer: Chesed (kindness/mercy)
questions.explanation: The servant prays for and acknowledges the 'kindness' (chesed) God shows to Abraham, reflecting divine faithfulness (Genesis 24:12, 27).

questions.question: True or False: Isaac was comforted after the death of his mother Sarah by taking Rebekah as his wife.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 24:67 explicitly states that Isaac loved Rebekah and was comforted after his mother’s death.

theological.title: Genesis Chapter 24 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Genesis Chapter 24 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was Abraham's primary concern when instructing his servant regarding Isaac's wife?
options: That the wife be from Abraham's country and kindred
That the wife be from the Canaanites
That Isaac choose his own wife
That the servant marry the wife instead
questions.correctAnswer: That the wife be from Abraham's country and kindred
questions.explanation: Abraham explicitly commands his servant not to take a wife for Isaac from the Canaanites but from his own country and kindred (Genesis 24:3-4). This shows the importance of covenantal lineage and separation from surrounding peoples. This accords with Deuteronomy 7:3-4, which forbids intermarriage with certain nations to preserve holiness. The New Testament affirms God's faithfulness to his promises to Abraham's seed (Galatians 3:16), and the necessity of godly heritage in spiritual lineage (2 Timothy 2:2).

questions.question: By what act did Abraham make his servant swear concerning the task of finding a wife for Isaac?
options: Putting his hand under Abraham's thigh
Raising his hand to heaven
Touching the altar
Kissing Abraham's hand
questions.correctAnswer: Putting his hand under Abraham's thigh
questions.explanation: Abraham asked his servant to put his hand under his thigh to swear an oath (Genesis 24:2-9). This act symbolized a serious covenantal oath related to the continuation of Abraham’s lineage, similar to other covenantal acts like circumcision (Genesis 17:9-14). This solemn oath underscores the gravity of divine promises and human obedience, resonating with biblical themes of covenant faithfulness (Psalm 89:34, Hebrews 6:13-18).

questions.question: What was the servant’s prayer criteria for identifying the right wife for Isaac at the well?
options: The woman who offers water to both him and his camels
The woman who greets him with bread
The woman who comes with a bridal party
The woman who knows Abraham personally
questions.correctAnswer: The woman who offers water to both him and his camels
questions.explanation: The servant prayed that the right wife would offer him water and also water his camels (Genesis 24:14). This sign indicated God's providential guidance and kindness, highlighting the active role of divine intervention in human affairs. It reflects God's covenant faithfulness and sovereign control over blessings (Psalm 23:1-3; Proverbs 3:5-6). The New Testament similarly teaches God’s providence in the affairs of believers (Romans 8:28).

questions.question: Which attribute of God is highlighted by the servant’s reliance on divine guidance throughout his mission?
options: God’s faithfulness and providence
God’s impatience
God’s silence
God’s judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God’s faithfulness and providence
questions.explanation: The servant consistently relies on God to lead him to the right wife, showing God’s faithfulness to His promises and providential care (Genesis 24:12-27). This echoes God’s faithful guidance of His people seen throughout Scripture (Psalm 25:10; Isaiah 42:16; Matthew 10:29-31). God’s providence ensures the fulfillment of His covenant promises (Romans 4:20-21).

questions.question: What is the significance of the servant giving Rebekah jewelry such as a golden earring and bracelets?
options: It signified a formal betrothal and the blessing of God’s provision
It was a bribe to convince her to come
It was a common trade practice of the region
It was a gift from Isaac himself
questions.correctAnswer: It signified a formal betrothal and the blessing of God’s provision
questions.explanation: The giving of jewelry to Rebekah (Genesis 24:22, 53) symbolizes the covenantal betrothal and God's gracious provision. Such tokens in the ancient Near East indicated a binding engagement (Exodus 32:2; Ruth 4:9-10). This reflects God’s redemptive plan and blessing on the marriage, pointing forward to Christ’s bride (Ephesians 5:25-27).

questions.question: How did Rebekah respond when asked if she would go with Abraham's servant?
options: She willingly agreed to go
She hesitated and refused
She asked for time to consult her family
She proposed another suitor
questions.correctAnswer: She willingly agreed to go
questions.explanation: Rebekah’s affirmative response to go with the servant (Genesis 24:58) shows her faith and submission to God’s providential leading. This act of obedience prefigures the willing submission expected of believers in God’s plan (Romans 12:1-2), and her faith aligns with that of Abraham and Sarah (Hebrews 11:11).

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by Abraham’s servant worshipping the LORD after finding Rebekah?
options: God’s sovereignty and faithful guidance
The servant’s personal pride
The blessing of wealth
The power of human effort
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereignty and faithful guidance
questions.explanation: The servant's worship after the successful finding of Rebekah (Genesis 24:26, 48, 52) highlights God’s sovereignty and faithfulness in accomplishing His promises. It underscores the biblical truth that God directs the steps of His people (Proverbs 16:9), and that all blessing flows from Him (James 1:17). This worship reflects trust in God’s providential control over salvation history.

questions.question: What does the servant’s concern about the woman’s willingness to follow him reveal about the nature of marriage in biblical theology?
options: Marriage requires willing consent and faith
Marriage is arranged without consent
Marriage is solely a family agreement
Marriage is a casual contract
questions.correctAnswer: Marriage requires willing consent and faith
questions.explanation: The servant’s question about whether the woman will willingly follow (Genesis 24:5) shows that consent and faith are essential components of marriage. This reflects the biblical understanding that marriage is a covenant entered into by willing parties (Ephesians 5:22-33). It also emphasizes the human responsibility to respond to God’s providential call.

questions.question: How does the narrative of Genesis 24 illustrate the doctrine of God’s providence?
options: By showing God’s active guidance over the servant’s mission
By depicting chance encounters with no divine involvement
By focusing on human planning alone
By illustrating God’s silence in critical moments
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God’s active guidance over the servant’s mission
questions.explanation: The chapter demonstrates God's providence through the servant’s prayer and the subsequent signs (Genesis 24:12-27). The narrative shows that God directs events to fulfill His promises, consistent with Scripture’s teaching on divine sovereignty (Psalm 37:23-24; Romans 8:28). This reinforces God’s care in the salvation history leading to Christ.

questions.question: What messianic theme is foreshadowed by the selection of Rebekah as wife for Isaac?
options: God’s promise of a chosen bride for His Son
The rejection of God's people
The end of the Abrahamic covenant
The fulfillment of the law only
questions.correctAnswer: God’s promise of a chosen bride for His Son
questions.explanation: Rebekah as the bride of Isaac prefigures the Church as the bride of Christ, the promised Seed (Genesis 24:67, Galatians 3:16; Ephesians 5:25-27). This typology highlights God's covenant faithfulness and the union between Christ and His redeemed people (Revelation 19:7-9).

questions.question: What is the significance of Isaac meditating in the field when Rebekah approaches?
options: It symbolizes spiritual preparation and divine timing
It shows Isaac was unaware of God’s plan
It indicates Isaac was indifferent to marriage
It was a coincidence with no theological meaning
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes spiritual preparation and divine timing
questions.explanation: Isaac’s meditation in the field at eventide (Genesis 24:63) signifies a posture of spiritual readiness and openness to God’s timing. This reflects biblical themes of waiting on the Lord (Psalm 27:14) and God’s perfect timing in redemption history (Ecclesiastes 3:1). It aligns with Christ’s own prayerful preparation (Luke 5:16).

questions.question: How does Genesis 24 demonstrate the biblical principle of covenant continuity?
options: By ensuring Isaac’s wife is from Abraham’s kin
By breaking ties with Abraham’s family
By marrying outside the covenant community
By disregarding God’s promises
questions.correctAnswer: By ensuring Isaac’s wife is from Abraham’s kin
questions.explanation: Abraham commands the servant to find a wife from his own kin (Genesis 24:3-4), demonstrating covenant continuity through lineage. This principle safeguards the covenant promises and identity of God’s people (Exodus 19:5-6; Deuteronomy 7:6). The New Testament also emphasizes spiritual lineage through faith (Romans 4:11-12).

questions.question: What does the servant’s detailed recounting of his mission to Laban and Bethuel reveal about biblical witness?
options: Honest testimony and reliance on God’s guidance are vital
Stories should be kept secret
Only kings can speak for God
Witnessing is unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: Honest testimony and reliance on God’s guidance are vital
questions.explanation: The servant openly relates his mission and God’s guidance (Genesis 24:34-48), showing the importance of truthful testimony about God’s work. This reflects the biblical call to witness to God's faithfulness (Acts 1:8; 1 Peter 3:15) and to glorify God through testimony (Psalm 66:16).

questions.question: What does Rebekah's covering herself with a veil signify when she meets Isaac?
options: Modesty and reverence in entering marriage
Shame and fear
Rebellion against tradition
Indifference to the marriage
questions.correctAnswer: Modesty and reverence in entering marriage
questions.explanation: Rebekah’s veiling (Genesis 24:65) indicates modesty and respect appropriate to a bride meeting her husband, aligning with biblical values of purity and honor (1 Corinthians 11:5-6; Song of Solomon 4:1-7). It foreshadows the bride of Christ’s purity (2 Corinthians 11:2).

questions.question: How does Genesis 24 illustrate the doctrine of salvation history?
options: By showing God’s providential orchestration of the lineage through Isaac
By focusing only on human effort without divine involvement
By ending the covenant promises with Abraham
By neglecting God’s promises
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God’s providential orchestration of the lineage through Isaac
questions.explanation: Genesis 24 highlights God’s active role in salvation history by orchestrating Isaac’s marriage to Rebekah, securing the covenant lineage (Genesis 24:1-67). This fits into the grand narrative of Scripture, where God preserves His redemptive plan culminating in Christ (Romans 11:28-29; Hebrews 11:8-12).

questions.question: What does the blessing given to Rebekah by her family reflect about God’s covenant blessings?
options: It expresses the hope for fruitfulness and dominion
It curses her for leaving
It reflects indifference
It is a secular family custom only
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses the hope for fruitfulness and dominion
questions.explanation: Rebekah’s blessing (Genesis 24:60) speaks of becoming 'mother of thousands of millions' and possessing the gates of enemies, reflecting God’s covenant blessings of fruitfulness and victory (Genesis 12:2-3; Psalm 127:3-5). This blessing anticipates the fulfillment of God’s promises through the Messiah’s seed.
